channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Czech Premier to Resign Amid Scandal
item.description: Prime Minister Petr Necas of the Czech Republic said Sunday that he would resign, following a corruption scandal involving a senior aide.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Petr Necas at a news conference on Sunday. He had initially reacted to a corruption scandal involving a senior aide with defiance.

item.title: The Education Revolution: Faltering Economy in China Dims Job Prospects for Graduates
item.description: Graduating seniors say that few are finding jobs — and some offers extended over the winter were being rescinded as the economy falters.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and SUE-LIN WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A job fair last month at Minzu University of China in Beijing. Companies have limited positions to offer graduating seniors.

item.title: China Dissident Says He’s Being Forced From N.Y.U.
item.description: Chen Guangcheng, the legal advocate, said he was being forced to leave the university over concerns that his activism was harming its relationship with China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: In a statement released Sunday, Mr. Chen Guangcheng said university officials were worried that his outspoken criticism of the Chinese government might threaten academic cooperation.

item.title: Qunu Journal: Mandela’s Absence Is Felt, if Not Addressed
item.description: The residents of the village where Mr. Mandela, now ailing with a lung infection, grew up seemed determined to press ahead with life as normal.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A choir at the Regina Mundi church in Soweto, South Africa, where parishioners prayed on Sunday for Nelson Mandela, who remained hospitalized.

item.title: Greek Leaders to Meet in Effort to Save Government
item.description: The prime minister’s decision to close the state broadcaster last week has led to a rift among the members of the governing coalition that could lead to early elections.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: A control room at the headquarters of the Greek state broadcaster ERT. The prime minister's decision last week to close ERT has put the governing coalition at risk.

item.title: Dozens Killed In Attacks Targeting Iraqi Shiites
item.description: Bombs exploded in five southern Shiite provinces, killing civilians, and attacks near Tikrit and Mosul struck security forces, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: A series of bombings in Shiite-majority areas of Iraq killed at least 30 people on Sunday. A blast in Najaf struck a produce market.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Republicans to Watch on Immigration
item.description: An immigration bill is likely to pass the Senate by the end of the month. The size and shape of the measure and the tone of the debate will be framed by Republicans in the next 10 days.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: After Plans Stall for Talks With South Korea, the North Sends an Invitation to the U.S.
item.description: The North indicated that it was moving toward negotiations after months of threats to launch nuclear strikes at the United States and South Korea.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Korean Central News Agency shows North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un with workers at a glass factory during a recent tour of North Phyongan Province.

item.title: 2 Polio Workers Killed in Pakistan
item.description: Two volunteers who were assisting in a polio immunization campaign were shot to death, the second such attack in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: India Ink: Experiments With Democracy in Bhutan
item.description: The second general election is underway in the Himalayan kingdom, which was until recently ruled by a monarch.
item.dc:creator: By OMAIR AHMAD
item.media:description: A statue of Lord Buddha at Kuensel Phodrang in Thimphu, Bhutan on May 20, 2012.

item.title: India Ink: Bihar Ally Leaves Opposition Coalition Over Modi’s Elevation
item.description: Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar ended the 17-year-old alliance of his party Janata Dal (United) with the Bharatiya Janata Party on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVAM VIJ
item.media:description: Nitish Kumar, chief minister of Bihar, at a conference on internal security in New Delhi on June 5.

item.title: North Korea Proposes High-Level Talks With U.S.
item.description: After months of rhetoric, North Korea said it was ready to discuss easing tensions and denuclearization with the United States.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: North Korea Proposes Talks With Washington
item.description: North Korea's top governing body on Sunday proposed high-level nuclear and security talks with the United States in an appeal sent just days after calling off talks with rival South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Soldiers Killed During Overnight Attacks in Benghazi
item.description: Six were killed early Saturday in assaults believed to be retaliation for the expulsion of a major militia from the city last weekend.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: U.S. to Keep Warplanes in Jordan, Pressing Syria
item.description: The move came as efforts were being made on multiple fronts on Saturday to increase the pressure on the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and THOM SHANKER

item.title: Police Storm Park in Istanbul, Setting Off a Night of Chaos
item.description: After 18 days of protests, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered his riot police to storm Gezi Park. As people fled the tear gas and water cannons, the police pursued them in the streets.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: The police attacked protesters with water cannons next to Gezi Park, in Istanbul’s Taksim Square on Saturday evening.

item.title: Iran Moderate Wins Presidency by a Large Margin
item.description: Hassan Rowhani, who advocates greater personal freedoms and a more conciliatory approach to the world, avoided a runoff in the election to replace Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Supporters of the newly elected president of Iran, Hassan Rowhani, took part in street festivities on Saturday after the announcement of his victory in Tehran.

item.title: Belgian Diamond Theft, Filled With Cinematic Thrills, Also Has a Blooper Reel
item.description: Since a meticulously planned theft on the windblown tarmac of the Brussels airport in February, the episode has veered from thriller to comedy, featuring a roundup of unusual suspects.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: Marc Bertoldi, left, at an extradition hearing last month, denied involvement in a diamond theft.

item.title: After Profits, Defense Contractor Faces the Pitfalls of Cybersecurity
item.description: Mike McConnell, who once led the National Security Agency, is now the chief architect of Booz Allen’s cyberstrategy — and among the executives facing tough questions after a data leak.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:credit: Mary F. Calvert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mike McConnell, vice chairman of Booz Allen Hamilton, was a director of national intelligence.

item.title: Afghan Forces, Taking Lead, Hold Steady in Violent District
item.description: The foreigners are mostly gone from Sangin District in the southern Taliban heartland, and its fate is up to the Afghans.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: Mohammad Naim Baluch, front, the governor of Helmand Province, visited the village of Sarwan Kala last month, the scene of fighting against the Taliban.

item.title: Borghese v. Borghese: Battle for a Royal Name
item.description: The issue over who may use the Borghese history, at least for marketing purposes, is at the center of one of the most contentious lawsuits facing trial in New York courts this summer.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY
item.media:credit: Nadav Neuhaus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francesco, left, Lorenzo and Amanda Borghese in New Jersey.

item.title: Coalition Party Weighs Support of Czech Leader
item.description: Party leaders are expected to meet to decide whether to stay in the coalition after an aide of Prime Minister Petr Necas was placed in custody for corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Paul Soros, Shipping Innovator, Dies at 87
item.description: Mr. Soros built Soros Associates, which has dominated the port-building industry and shifted international trade and production patterns through its shipping innovations.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.
item.media:description: Paul Soros build Soros Associates, which has dominated the port-building industry.

item.title: The Lede: After Long Night of Counting, Post-Election Celebrations in Iran
item.description: The Lede followed developments in Iran on Saturday, where Hassan Rowhani, a moderate cleric supported by the country’s reformist movement, was declared the winner of Friday’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of the running vote tally in Iran on the Web site of the international public opinion and research firm IPOS.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Election Day in Iran
item.description: The Lede is following developments in Iran, where voters went to the polls on Friday in the first presidential election since the disputed contest in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of the running vote tally in Iran on the Web site of the international public opinion and research firm IPOS.
